name: Android Hacknight
description:
PHX Android and Phoenix Google Developer Group Present: Android Hacknight

Come down and bring your project, question or new cool thing you want to show. Are you using something with Android? Do you have something you're working on? Do you want to learn how to get going with Android? Have a question or a problem with something you're working on? Then this is for you. This is an open hack night.

Android Book authors Donn Felker and Mike Wolfson will be present along with Sheldon McGee and other Android professionals.

name: Android Hacknight
description:
Bring your projects, questions, ideas or just come on down to hack on an Android related project. Android Experts will be present to help further the process. 

You can also come and showcase your new project (5 minute showcase) if you'd like. 

Come one, come all and bring your Android goodness with you.

name: Android Studio Tips
description:
Android Studio is a new IDE from Google currently in "early access preview" based on IntelliJ IDEA. Michael will review some interesting features of Android Studio that might make you consider giving it a try. This session assumes basic knowledge of Java and Android development. 

Speaker - Michael Bailey, Engineering Director - Android, American Express

Michael is the Engineering Director for the Android team responsible for American Express’ flagship consumer Android apps in the U.S. market. Development on these apps began in 2010. 

Since joining the company in 2008, Michael has worked on a number initiatives at American Express including analytics, enterprise content management, AmexLabs, iOS apps, international mobile applications, NFC payments, the U.S. homepage and the U.S. online card applications site.

Michael holds a BS in Computer Science from Harvey Mudd College and an MS in Computer Science from the University of Southern California, where he specialized in computer security. 

Including the US Consumer Apps that Michael works on0, American Express has 8 Android apps in the US Play Store (https://play.google.com/store/apps/developer?id=American%20Express) and more in the International Play Stores.

name: Android Open Hack
description:
Bring your projects, questions, ideas or just come on down to hack on an Android related project. Android Experts will be present to help further the process. 

You can also come and showcase your new project (5 minute showcase) if you'd like. 

Come one, come all and bring your Android goodness with you.

name: Android Open Hack
description:
Bring your projects, questions, ideas or just come on down to hack on an Android related project. Android Experts will be present to help further the process. 

You can also come and showcase your new project (5 minute showcase) if you'd like. 

Come one, come all and bring your Android goodness with you.

name: Google IO Extended
description:
We will be gathering this time to watch the keynote presentation, discuss events/things that happened at Google IO and communicate with Android Experts that Google has identified. Feel free to still bring your Android Project that you're working on as we will also be hacking away while all of this takes place. Think of this as a big Google IO Extended meet up.

From the IO Extended Site -

Brought to you by our Google Developer Groups, Student Ambassadors, and local developers, Google I/O Extended lets you experience the magic and innovation of Google I/O remotely. Part viewing experience and part community building, I/O Extended programming includes everything from live streaming the Google I/O content to local developer demos, hackathons, and speaker sessions.

Our meeting host-

Our normal meeting hosts will be attending the conference in person, so we have a very special person lined up to run the meeting.  Special thanks to Brad Westphall (of Phoenix Javascript Meetup fame) for stepping in and helping our group.

We welcome our new sponsor -

http://photos4.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/c/3/a/2/event_361250082.jpegWe are pleased to announce that we have a new sponsor for GDGPhoenix.  They will be bringing food and beverages to this meeting.

 

 

Swag-

We have confirmed a few giveaways: we will have coupons for AndroidWear watches (the devices are not available yet).  A pass for AnDevCon San Fran in November, T-Shirts, book, and some other surprises.
how_to_find_us: When driving to CO+HOOTS, if you get on the 'inside' lane of the road (from the light-rail lane) you will be able to navigate easier (it is tricky to drive to CH the 1st time)

name: Android Open Hack
description: Come out and work on your project or just talk about Google IO and maybe check out the Android TV I'll bring.

name: Android Open Hack
description:
"Live Coding Session: - Intro to Android Testing using Espresso"

"Michael will be doing a brief live coding session, where he will demonstrate the basics of writing your first Espresso test. Basic knowledge of Android and Java development will be assumed"

Presenter: Michael Bailey

name: Android Open Hack
description:
Switching our normal meetup to a week earlier due to holiday.

This month, we will have a presentation from Mike Wolfson about implementing Material Design.

In this session I will describe:
– What ‘Material’ is
– Usage of motion and animations
– New Components (buttons, menu’s, sliders, etc)
– View layouts (using elevation and grid metrics)
– Style (colors, icons, typography)
– Developing for Android
– Developing for the Web

name: Intro to XPRIZE for Global Learning
description:
The XPRIZE Foundation has created a new XPRIZE for Global Learning http://learning.xprize.org. The $15M XPRIZE will be awarded for the open-source Android App that best accelerates learning for 7-12 year kids during an 18-month trial beginning two years from now.

Jono Bacon, Director of Community Development for the XPRIZE Foundation, will be speaking at a charity event in Phoenix on the morning of January 15. Jono will introduce the Global Learning XPRIZE and will talk about his efforts to build a world-wide community to compete and collaborate towards developing the learning app.

PHX Android members are welcome to attend. RSVP required. Suggested donation: $100.

http://www.starshine100thmonkey.eventbrite.com

Contact [masked] for more information.

name: Understanding Android Build Variants with Donn Felker
description:
Donn Felker will be giving us a presentation on Android Build Variants. Learn how to develop, free and pro versions of your applications. How to perform debug only configurations and how to use Build Variants in your day to day Android Development. 

This event is free and will be hosted at the new CoWorking space: DeskHub. We will have a room with desks and chairs and a large projector this time! Woo!

DeskHub is located in Scottsdale on Chaparral and Scottsdale Road. It is in the same parking lot as the "Roaring Fork" restaurant, in the 4900 building on the 4th floor. Enter the 4900 building and take the elevator to the 4th floor and turn left. You'll see DeskHub's sign and we will be in there.
how_to_find_us: Scottsdale Road and Chaparral Road. Same parking lot as the "Roaring Fork" restraunt, but we are next door in the 4900 building on the 4th floor at DeskHub (a new coworking space).

name: Creating Cross-Platform Apps with Ionic (PhoneGap/etc) with Sheldon McGee
description: Brief presentation about Ionic including what it is and how it's not "just PhoneGap".  Then a demo about some of the features. Bring a laptop and by the end you'll have an app ready to publish! Okay, not quite "published" since I'm sure even Google has some standards but you will have an APK with "Hello World" working.

name: Bugdroid Style (Material Design/etc) with Mike Wolfson
description:
It has always been challenging to chase Android fashion. For many years, the “style-makers” were pushing designs that would look more appropriate on an iPhone, or that were beautiful and unique masterpieces, yet impossible to actually implement. This was compounded by the fact that the formal guidelines were unclear, and incomplete. This made the role of an Android Interface developer very challenging.

In recent years, I have participated in many high-profile “UI refresh” projects. I have learned a lot from these projects, and will share a few key lessons I have learned from this practical experience.

I will discuss:
– how to build beautiful interfaces that are universally styled, responsive and beautiful
– strategies to work with designers and stake-holders to enhance workflow
– which key Android framework components that should be used to build flexible UI code
– the important concepts of the new ‘Material Design Guidelines

Come to this presentation to learn the techniques you will need to be ready for the next Android fashion fad.
“Fashions fade, style is eternal.” — Yves Saint-Laurent

name: Background tasks and loading in Fragments with Matthew Whitmer
description:
Download the code for Matthews talk here: 

http://1drv.ms/1LrEP05

You can follow along with the code in your IDE as well. :)

name: Cross Platform Mobile with Less Code using Xamarin C# with Rob Zmudzinski
description:
At this MeetUp Rob will cover ... 

• What is Xamarin?

• How does it compare with developing with Java?

• Xamarin and Java bindings - calling java code from Xamarin.

• How does Xamarin achieve cross-platform code reuse? - Portable Class Libraries.

• Xamarin Forms - achieving UI reuse across platforms while leaving room for the platform specific.

Check out Rob's website here - http://www.phoenixroberts.com
Follow Rob on Twitter - https://twitter.com/phxroberts

Rob has been freelancing for 10 years and programming for 25. His background is in Wall St IT - Electronic Trading Systems. Rob's clients have included JP Morgan, Royal Bank of Scottland, Barrett-Jackson, Pepsi Cola, Cantor Fitzgerald.

name: Getting Started with RxJava with Donn Felker
description: Do keep hearing about RxJava or Reactive Extensions? Are you not entirely sure of what it is and how or why you'd want to use it? In this session, we'll cover some basics of RxJava (by using RxAndroid). When you leave you should have basic understanding of RxJava Observables, Subjects and Observers.

name: Arizona's First Quarterly Hackathon Powered by Adora
description:
Dear Members,
Come hack the weekend away for a good cause. The Talent Network, and ASU Talent Initiative focused on helping connect the student Dev community with local startups and business is hosting the 1st of what will be a quarterly hack-at-hon. Food, energy, and entertainment (yes you know you will be entertaining each other) will be provided. If you want to learn more about the problem, visit the website at http://talentnetwork.co/hackathon/.

name: Material all devices using AppCompat with Mike Wolfson
description:
Android 5.0 was one of the more exciting releases ever - especially with the introduction of the Material design. The specifications describe a beautiful UI, that can be a challenging for developers to implement, particularly if they must support backwards compatibility.

It just became easier with the release of the 'Android Design Support Library' (and the previously released 'AppCompat Library'). Developers now have the tools that make it simple to create Material compliant apps - that will work and look great on almost all devices (even ones running 2.1).

In this presentation I will highlight some important components of these libraries, and demonstrate how to use them effectively.

It is just the beginning for Material design - come learn about the important tools that make it easy to be part of the revolution.
how_to_find_us: Enter through the back door of the space - free parking on street or in lot to East of space

name: How to automate testing with Josh Coffman
description:
Josh is a Software Engineer and Architect with more than 20 years of experience. He got started in Android nearly 5 years ago while building the server side of mobile platforms, and transitioned to building the Android client for those mobile systems. He cares about clean code that is easy to maintain and reducing development friction.

Here is a brief outline of what will be coverd:

• testing quickly

• robolectric, and other tools

• trouble with flavors

• automation

• build server

name: IoT DevFest
description:
*You must have a ticket for this event, they are available now* 

http://www.iotdevfest.com/

------------------------ 
We are excited about this cool event.   We are bringing in some top notch speakers (and expect a great community) for a unique intimate event.

The speaker list is on the website and a schedule is coming soon:

http://www.iotdevfest.com/speakers/

You can expect a single track of excellent nationally recognized speakers and a unique opportunity to learn about the Internet of Things.
Our venue is awesome (MAC), and we have lined up great sponsors (shout out to Google Developers,  Octoblu and LocalMotors).  We will have swag, food, and great content.

We are charging a nominal fee (required to RSVP).  Want to come and can't afford the entry fee?  Contact us and we likely will take care of you.

name: Creating apps using MVVM (and more!) with Rob Zmudzinski
description:
MVVM and Data binding help keep our code "clean" and allows us to remove boilerplate findViewById() calls as well as having to manually update those views in the code. Decoupling our views from our models also provides with increased testability of our non-UI code. Covered in this session will be

• Creating bindings in XML

• Object/value converstions

• How the Android data binding library compares to frameworks like butterknife

• How and where to use data binding and how and where it should not be used.

Rob has been freelancing for 10 years and programming for 25. His background is in Wall St IT - Electronic Trading Systems. Rob's clients have included JP Morgan, Royal Bank of Scottland, Barrett-Jackson, Pepsi Cola, Cantor Fitzgerald. 

Check out Rob's website here:

http://www.phoenixroberts.com

Follow Rob on Twitter:

https://twitter.com/phxroberts

name: Android Beginners Study Jam - Kickoff
description:
Attendance Formhttp://bit.ly/1WMjL9D

Signup on Udacity http://bit.ly/20MyU1b

Slides:

https://tooshel.github.io/studyjampres/#/11

Udacity, in cooperation with Google, just released a new course called “Android Development for Beginners”. In this case, the “Beginners” are people new to programming as well as new to Android. The only requirements are a computer (hopefully a laptop so you can bring it along), some basic computer usage skills, and a willingness to learn and explore. It has 3 lessons and a final the estimate is that it can be done with a 16-20 hour commitment over the course of a month or so.

Getting started with any new course on a subject as complex as Android is a monumental task . . . even with help from the amazing instructors at Udacity. That’s why GDG Phoenix is proud to support the course and is running a “Study Jam” where we meet regularly (in person and possibly through Google Hangouts) and go over questions people have and provide general support while people do the course. Watching the videos and participating in the course is up to you . . . but we’re here to help and motivate you to reach the Final Project!

Feb 25th is the kickoff meeting and first Study Jam but feel free to start RIGHT NOW. The course is online and free and the first lesson you don’t need any development tools installed.

https://www.udacity.com/account/affiliate/GoogleStudyJams

The secret to “free” is that you click on the “Access Course Materials” button instead of the “Start Free Trial” button.

https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/K0zKATphnHP3xOVK3ICMP5_sz4aza8a1XXQ35MLnwOqiCpFzbnUXJ4qzs8-oe0Iy-D5M_rgaQGEq_yxKtTo3jA_drmcuGqpLqb7F_P6qTFh6Z3ObnInkKdQMFJH0y3todW_FN4K2

On Thursday Feb 25th at 6pm bring your laptop and your headphones and get ready to start working! We’ll make sure everyone has Android Studio installed and is ready to get going and will do a short intro at the start of the class and answer those nagging questions you might have like “What does an ice cream sandwich have to do with Android development?”
how_to_find_us: Questions . . . join the slack channel: http://gdgphoenix.herokuapp.com/

name: Android Beginners Study Jam - Second Session
description:
Updated location! Sorry for the short notice but we had to change the venue. This time it'll be far north Phoenix and next time we'll move it south. Here is a map of the new location.

https://www.google.com/maps/d/edit?mid=zB825ebXzomc.koNV0xQk0NNY&usp=sharing

We need to provide security with full names 24 hours in advance and for everyone to bring their ID. Meetup has no real name requirement so, instead, you can just fill out the attendance form in advance and I'll submit those names too. Sorry for the inconvenience.

https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1pU5la3rbrRTZ_iiNC_KdOx1-u8eNQXkZGlZ16rm8eSE/viewform

We don't share this info with anyone and this form is just to keep track of attendance (for certificates, prizes, etc).

See you soon!

Sheldon

=============

For this session, we expect you have already finished Lesson 1A and 1B, Practice Set 1, and are well into Lesson 2A and 2B. The original schedule said you should be done with 2A and 2B but we’ll let it slide if you are a bit behind. We are happy to have you even if you didn’t make it to the kickoff but please make sure you signup here and get going on the lessons:

https://www.udacity.com/account/affiliate/GoogleStudyJams

This meeting will only be for 2 hours, 6-8pm, we’ll have it at the same location for now but if we get enough signups we’ll move it . . . so be prepared for a venue change. You do not have to attend every Study Jam but we do encourage you to attend as many as possible. Community is everything.

Drinks and food will be provided again and the plan is we have something other than pizza. You will need your laptop and headphones and are free to run through the Udacity videos if you are ahead of what we are reviewing or if you have Android Studio installed and we’re troubleshooting that, etc.  Below is the standard stuff I’ll put on every Study Jam this series. Hope to see everyone soon!

=================

The only requirements are a computer (hopefully a laptop so you can bring it along), some basic computer usage skills, and a willingness to learn and explore. With three lessons and a final the estimate is that it can be done with a 20 hour commitment over the course of a month or so.

Getting started with any new course on a subject as complex as Android is a monumental task . . . even with help from the amazing instructors at Udacity. That’s why GDG Phoenix is proud to support the course and is running a “Study Jam” where we meet regularly and go over questions people have and provide general support while people do the course. Watching the videos and participating in the course is up to you . . . but we’re here to help and motivate you to reach the Final Project!

Feel free to start *right now* and get caught up. The course is online and free and for the first lesson you don’t need any development tools installed.

https://www.udacity.com/account/affiliate/GoogleStudyJams

The secret to “free” is that you click on the “Access Course Materials” button instead of the “Start Free Trial” button.

https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/K0zKATphnHP3xOVK3ICMP5_sz4aza8a1XXQ35MLnwOqiCpFzbnUXJ4qzs8-oe0Iy-D5M_rgaQGEq_yxKtTo3jA_drmcuGqpLqb7F_P6qTFh6Z3ObnInkKdQMFJH0y3todW_FN4K2

Have fun! Learn lots! See you soon!
how_to_find_us: Don't forget to reach out on slack. Signup: http://gdgphoenix.herokuapp.com/ Web: https://gdgphoenix.slack.com/

name: Android Beginners Study Jam - Third Session
description:
Not having a 140 char limit means I can really tell a story but if you don’t have time, here is the big picture:

--Moved to 7pm, food will be there at 6:30 though.

--Venue is Gangplank Chandler . . . should be interesting.

--Everyone is welcome, even if you are behind in the course.

For this session we expect you have already finished everything though Lesson 3A and 3B and are thinking about the Five Things Final Project. If you haven't made it that far, well, this is a volunteer gig so there isn’t much I can do . . . and beside, I’m a bit behind too! Plus, Lesson 3 is supposed to be the most difficult so this study jam will be very important. There is a 3 week gap between sessions so we should all be able to make up the lost ground and be ready with questions about Lesson 3 and the Final. We are happy to have you even if you didn’t make it to the kickoff and the second session but please make sure you signup here and get to work because you are really behind!

https://www.udacity.com/account/affiliate/GoogleStudyJams

This meeting will be for about 2 hours and we moved it to 7pm so the people in the North Valley have a chance to make it this far south (specifically, all the experts from Amex!). The food will be there at 6:30 though so show up early and we can chat. You do not have to attend every Study Jam but we do encourage you to attend as many as possible. Community is everything.

Drinks and food will be provided and the plan is we have something other than pizza, but we’ll see. You will need your laptop and headphones and are free to run through the Udacity videos if you are ahead of what we are reviewing.  Below is the standard stuff I’ll put on every Study Jam this series. Hope to see everyone soon!

=================

Udacity, in cooperation with Google, released a new course called “Android Development for Beginners”. In this case, the “Beginners” are people new to programming as well as new to Android. The only requirements are a computer (hopefully a laptop so you can bring it along), some basic computer usage skills, and a willingness to learn and explore. With three lessons and a final the estimate is that it can be done with a 20 hour commitment over the course of a month or so.

Getting started with any new course on a subject as complex as Android is a monumental task . . . even with help from the amazing instructors at Udacity. That’s why GDG Phoenix is proud to support the course and is running a “Study Jam” where we meet regularly and go over questions people have and provide general support while people do the course. Watching the videos and participating in the course is up to you . . . but we’re here to help and motivate you to reach the Final Project!

Feel free to start *right now* and get caught up. The course is online and free and for the first lesson you don’t need any development tools installed.

https://www.udacity.com/account/affiliate/GoogleStudyJams

The secret to “free” is that you click on the “Access Course Materials” button instead of the “Start Free Trial” button.

https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/K0zKATphnHP3xOVK3ICMP5_sz4aza8a1XXQ35MLnwOqiCpFzbnUXJ4qzs8-oe0Iy-D5M_rgaQGEq_yxKtTo3jA_drmcuGqpLqb7F_P6qTFh6Z3ObnInkKdQMFJH0y3todW_FN4K2

Have fun! Learn lots! See you soon!
how_to_find_us: Slack is a good way and so is @tooshel on twitter.  https://gdgphoenix.slack.com and http://gdgphoenix.herokuapp.com/

name: Coffee and Code and GCP Next
description:
Join us the after GCP Next (Google’s big Cloud Platform conference) to review the keynotes (yes, there are two), go over announcements, and do a code lab or two! We’ll provide the bagels, coffee and (maybe) pizza and you come ready to take on a challenge. If you’ve never used the Google Cloud Platform (or even if you wonder what this “cloud” thing is) you are more than welcome to come and learn about it and if you’re a cloud veteran we’d love to see you too (to help out the others and learn a thing or two yourself). 

For many of us, the real excitement was around node on App Engine so we'll have a demo on that for sure. See you then!

name: I/O Extended
description:
Join us in Tempe for a recap of everything Google I/O from the keynote and announcements to recaps of the best sessions.vSeveral people who experienced the festival will be there to answer questions and share experiences. Food and drinks will be provided and we even have a few things to give away (including a personal favorite, hint here: http://bit.ly/22pm9qv). Plus, we'll be in this new meeting space and it's always fun to check out a new space.

Tempe Transportation Center, Cassano Room

200 E. Fifth Street, 2nd Floor

Tempe, AZ 85281

This is in downtown Tempe and parking might be tricky but after 6pm there should be some good options. Feel free to explore and let me know what you found.

Hope to see you there!

Publicity Disclaimer: Any publicity distributed for this event must include a statement worded as follows: "This activity is not sponsored by the City of Tempe or the Tempe Transportation Center.

name: Progressive Web Apps Summit EXTENSION
description:
Join us on Thursday, July 28th at 6:30pm to learn more about Progressive Web Apps (PWA). We'll start the evening with some food and drinks and a showing the keynote from the PWA summit last month. Then we'll do some Q and A about the keynote and PWAs. Next we'll add a few features to a website to give it some PWA features. Finally, everyone can do the same to their own site after going though a code lab. Should be a fun night of learning for everyone.

If you want to add some PWA features to your own site the first requirement is that it's a secure site using ssl (https). If you want to get started on a real site right away that's the first thing to think about. Thanks to "Let's Encrypt" (https://letsencrypt.org/) we were able to add certs to our example site for free . . . we'll cover that too!

See you soon!

name: Android Apps, Instant and Everywhere with Yasmine Evjen
description:
During the IO 2016 keynote, Google announced Instant Apps. Instant Apps allow you to run native Android apps without having to install them on your phone. Later that week Google powered up your Chromebook, by introducing Android Apps to Chrome OS. 

Android Apps are going to be available on many devices with varying screen sizes. And you'll be able to complete an in-app task without installing the app. How do we craft a modular and responsive, cohesive Android app experience?

Yasmine Evjen is a UX designer, she believes in pen before pixel, user testing, and research. She can be found advocating for diversity in tech, using code and design to solve problems, and explaining to her daughter that Google isn't a real person. She's hooked on mobile and wearables; you can hear her talk about them on Material Podcast, a weekly show about Google and Android on Relay FM. She was once retweeted by First Lady Michelle Obama.

Food and cold drinks will be waiting when you arrive. Park for free in the structure across the street. Hope you can join us!

name: Mastering Material Motion with Mike Wolfson
description:
One of the foundations of Material Design is Motion. Effective motion can be used to provide user feedback, guide interaction focus, establish visual relationships between elements, and provide important polish and delight. Creating apps with effective motion hasn't always been simple, but I have learned some techniques to make it easy. Come to this session where I will show you how to use touch feedback, transitions and animations to make your applications come alive with effective motion and be more enjoyable for your users.

Mike Wolfson, Able Android LLC

Mike is a passionate mobile designer/developer working out of Phoenix. He has been working in the software field for more than 20 years, and with Android since its introduction. Currently, he develops Android applications for an IoT startup, in the automotive and payments space. He is a Google Developer Expert in Android, and the author of the book “Android Developer Tools Essentials” published by O’Reilly.Mike has spoken about Android and mobile development at a variety of conferences and user groups (including Oscon, AnDevCon, GDGSv, Droidcon Turin, and others). When he is not geeking out about phones, he enjoys the outdoors (snowboarding, hiking, scuba diving), collecting PEZ dispensers, and chasing his young (but quick) daughter.

Food and cold drinks will be waiting when you arrive. Park for free in the structure across the street. Hope you can join us!

name: Wrapping the Firebase Data Model with Kylan Johnson
description:
The new Firebase software stack is both comprehensive and powerful.  It provides even the smallest dev teams with the tools to create a great app because so much of the heavy lifting has been done for you.  

One of the heavier "lifts" a dev teams can undertake is the creation and implementation of their app's data model.  Fortunately, Firebase ships with a lightning quick NoSQL database that enables realtime data syncing, data persistence and offline mode!

In this talk, we'll focus on the Firebase Realtime Database by:Demonstrating how to interact with our data model via the Firebase APIDeciding both what to persist and how to persist it.  Talking about how to maximize testability with our final app

At the end, I hope the mountain that is Firebase might be a little more approachable for all.

Food and cold drinks will be waiting when you arrive. Park for free in the structure across the street. Hope you can join us!

name: IoT Devfest
description:
Buy tickets here: https://ti.to/iot-devfest/2nd-annual-IoT-Devfest

Discount code: PHXANDROID

Website: http://www.iotdevfest.com/

IoT Devfest is a single track event focused on the Internet of Things (IoT). Android Things will be covered so it's well worth any Android Developers to come and check it out.

We'll have speakers flying in from all over the country and of course some of our very own local talent. We have many amazing sponsors already lined up including Google and Octoblu but we are looking for more. Please register soon and join us at the Mesa Arts Center on Jan 21st!

name: Cloud NEXT Extended!
description:
Cloud NEXT Extended! is a chance for us to bring a small part of the Cloud Next 17 event to Phoenix. We will do a short intro to GCP and go over some of the announcements from the March 8-10th event. We will also show a few key momenents from the keynotes.  Then we want to go over one of the most popular code labs and then let everyone choose a code lab on their own.

Bring a laptop! You won't need any special software since most of the code labs happen "in the cloud" using the Google Cloud Shell (which we'll go over).

We'll provide pizza and drinks and FREE PARKING (which is significant if you've been to the Tempe location lately). . . oh, and we have a little prize to give away. Don't get too excited it's really little!

name: Kotlin Intro for Beginners by a Beginner
description:
Josh is going to do an introduction into Kotlin. What is Kotlin? What benefits does it offer? What can it do to make your job better? All these questions answered, and pizza.

Come join us and check out a new venue, Galvanize. They require registration, so please register here:

https://phxandroid4-27-17.eventbrite.com

Hope to see you there!

name: Google I/O EXTENSION!
description:
Join us at CO+HOOTS for a recap of everything Google I/O from the keynote and announcements to recaps of the best sessions. Several members of the community will be on hand to share their experience and answer questions. Food and drinks will be provided and we even have a few things to give away. Plus, we'll be at CO+HOOTS! That's reason enough to make the trip.

Bring your laptop because we will do a codelab or two for the second hour!

name: Nodebots Day 2017!
description:
Unfortunately, Nodebots Day 2017 is sold out . . . tickets only lasted 20 minutes . . . but that doesn't mean you can't stop by and see how the competition is going! The battle begins sometime after 4pm (can't say when because people always want more time).   

More info here:

https://ti.to/monteslu/nodebots-day-phx-2017

name: RecyclerView: The Ins and Outs . . . an Android talk by Adam MacDonald
description:
Join us on Thursday Aug 24th as Adam explains RecyclerView for Android. I'd love to elaborate but I can't get out of my head that on a Mac, it must be called "TrashView", right? Or that an alternative title could be "RecyclerView: more exciting than a ListView". Both terrible I know!

We'll be at galvanize and we'll have some food so I hope to see you there as Adam dazzles us! 

Sheldon

name: Building Android Design Specifications with Arni Maack
description:
Let’s talk about the forgotten step between design and development. We’ve all been there . . you finally received a PSD named:

ModernMaterialV2_FINAL_v3_FINAL_REALLY_FINAL_rev_b(3).psd

(or maybe .sketch if you’re lucky) and you think you’re ready to rock. Let’s talk about the mysterious artifact called design specification and what it ideally should contain. How is a design specification different from a design and who is responsible for putting it together… spoiler alert, it’s probably you!

name: How espresso works . . . Android talk with Michael Bailey
description:
Speaker: Michael Bailey, Principal Engineer, American Express

Espresso is a key part of the Android Test Support Library from Google. Espresso can be a great tool for automating UI testing. Come learn about the internals of how Espresso works. This will help you write fast, reliable tests, and better troubleshoot tests when they fail. You will learn about ViewActions, ViewAssertions and IdlingResources.

This talk assumes knowledge of Espresso. Please go thru this Code Lab prior to the event: https://codelabs.developers.google.com/codelabs/android-testing/index.html?index=..%2F..%2Findex#0

name: Introduction to Go with Nathan Jenan PLUS, a holiday celebration!
description:
Join us at 6:30 for some food and conversation (and drinks if Chris shows up! :)) as we celebrate 10 years of GDGs around the world and, you know, the holiday season. We have a few surprises we don't want to spoil it but you'll want to try and make it to this one! Especially Adam. He's going to want to go for sure.

At about 7:30 or so Nathan is going to do an Intro to Go talk described below. Immediately after we have few items to give away so we'll be spinning the big wheel! Oh, I guess that was the surprise. Oh well, at least you don't know what we are giving away!

We moved the meeting so we could team up with the Go meetup! The event is cross-posted here: https://www.meetup.com/Golang-Phoenix/events/245856090/ 

===

Go is a statically typed, compiled, garbage collected language created by Google.  It has a focus on concurrency, and produces self-contained, executable binaries instead of requiring an interpreter or virtual machine to run on.  Nathan Jenan will be going over the basics of the language and showing why it has quickly become a favorite of the DevOps community.

name: IoT Devfest 2018 (Now with Workshops!)
description:
• What we'll do
This is the 3rd Annual IoT Devfest! As usual we have some of the best speakers and new this year are workshops that cover the IoT spectrum. More info about speakers and workshops here:

https://www.iotdevfest.com/

Get discounted tickets with this link:

https://ti.to/iot-devfest/iot-devfest-2018/discount/GDGPHOENIX

Hope to see you there!

• What to bring
Laptop and micro usb cables will come in handy for the workshops!

• Important to know

name: IoT Devfest Extended
description:
Did you miss IoT Devfest? No problem! Come by for this recap by a few that did get to go! We'll have a light dinner, some demo's of the hardware found at the event, a recap what happened, and a few things to raffle off. Even if you DID go to IoT Devfest you'll want to go because we have a special surprise for people that bring their badge back and speak about their experience.

Did you go to the badge hacking session? If so, bring your badge hack by and we'll load up the new firmware!

name: TensorFlow DevSummit Extension
description:
What is TensorFlow DevSummit?
TensorFlow Dev Summit brings together a diverse mix of machine learning users from around the world for a full day of highly technical talks, demos, and conversation with the TensorFlow team and community.

The TensorFlow DevSummit happened in Mountain View on March 30. This "extended" event is to go over what was announced and review how machine learning is changing how we write code in the years to come.

Speakers:
James Clohessy
James attended the Tensoflow Devsummit and will talk about that a bit but he is also using Tensorflow now.

Erik Wilson
All about Tensorflow.js

Mike Wolfson
Intro to AI

Always a good idea to bring your laptop. There will be food and drinks as usual . . . hope to see you there!

name: Kelsey Hightower - Kubernetes and the path to Serverless
description:
KELSEY HIGHTOWER
Google
Kelsey is a strong open source advocate focused on building simple tools that make people smile.

name: Nodebots Day 2018
description:
As usual, Nodebots Day sold out in few hours so I didn't get a chance to post about it. But lucky for us I was able to scrounge together parts for a few extra bots! If you have any interest in robotics this event is for you. And feel free to bring a kid along! The event is TODAY (assuming you are reading it this Saturday morning the 28th) starting at 9:30 and the competition is at 4:30. We will build a chassis, wire it up, build a controller and wire it up, learn about chippers for programming, decorate, and then BATTLE! Three ways to win this time . . . best design, single elimination battle brackets (just push the competitor off the board), and then the final brawl where all bots enter and only one can win. All you need is a Macbook, Chromebook or an Android phone (and if you don't have one people are happy to share).

Tickets for the event were $35 so bring a way to pay (the parts you get to take home are worth AT LEAST that) and email me at [masked] and I'll hold it for you (and if I run out I'll let you know).

If you can't make it early you can still stop by at 4:30 and check out the competition. Hope to see you there!
how_to_find_us: Same building as the old Heatsync just a few doors down. Use the same parking lot in the back!

name: Setup Android Things at Heatsync
description:
Every 3rd Thursday we host the night at Heatsync Labs and this month a few of us are bringing an Android Things kit and are finally going to put it together! If you have some hardware bring it on down and lets see what we can do.

You can pick up a kit at https://androidthings.withgoogle.com/ but it's fairly expensive. That kit was given away at Google I/O in May this year and 60 lucky people who attended the Android Things workshop at IoT Devfest in January got the exact same kit.
how_to_find_us: It's a few doors down from the old Heatsync . . . parking in the same parking lot across from the children's museum

name: Android Things hack day at Heatsync
description:
Every 3rd Thursday we host the night at Heatsync Labs. This month we are bringing in a few and Android Things kits and want to dig in on the software now that the hardware is built. Last month we learned that the "Nearby API" was used to facilitate communication between the Android Things App and the Android Things Device which is what made it so easy to switch between demos on the device itself. But now it's time to load something of our own on the device!

You can pick up a kit at https://androidthings.withgoogle.com/ but it's fairly expensive ($199). That kit was given away at Google I/O in May this year and 60 lucky people who attended the Android Things workshop at IoT Devfest in January did a workshop with the exact same kit. We have an extra one you can borrow too! So come on by even if you don't have the hardware.
how_to_find_us: It's a few doors down from the old Heatsync . . . parking in the same parking lot across from the children's museum

name: Holiday Party, Prizes, and build a LEG Graham Cracker House
description:
Hello!

Come join us Thursday December 20th at Heatsync Labs for a holiday celebration! We'll have good food (i.e. probably not pizza), drinks, prizes and best of all building Graham Cracker Houses! A few weeks ago we build one in the lab and it was the most fun we've had since Nodebots day! If you want to build a house, sign up below since supplies are limited. We'll have prizes for "best use of Bugdroid" and "some other category we'll think of later". And kids are welcome too of course! (Pro tip: have them work on "the furniture" or "decorations for inside the house" while you get the main structure in place.)

https://goo.gl/forms/y7oEYc8aMQdsbG4g1

We will start building at 6pm and will be there till 10pm but you can show up anytime. Dinner will arrive around 7pm. Leave yourself at least 2 hours to build and make sure you are around at 9pm for the raffle (and hopefully most of the LEG houses are done so we can pick winners). If you have a special food or drink request please let me know.

Sheldon

name: PHX Android: Kotlin and MotionLayout
description:
We will be kicking off PHX Android for 2019, starting with Kotlin and MotionLayout. Study the finer points of Kotlin with us as we cover training materials from JetBrains. More details to come.

Kotlin Workshop is available content:
https://github.com/JetBrains/kotlin-workshop

name: IoT Devfest 2019
description:
Tickets are required for IoT Devfest. Get them here:

https://ti.to/iot-devfest/iot-devfest-2019

To learn more and see a bit about last year check out the website at:

https://www.iotdevfest.com/

IoT Devfest is a one day event focused on the Internet of Things. This is the 4th year of the event. We have a fast paced speaker track with 25 minute talks and multiple concurrent 2 hour hands on workshops. Last year we had 11 amazing talks as well as 9 hands on hardware workshops with speakers from around the world. The response to the workshops was overwhelming and this year in the new venue it will be better than ever!

name: Motion Layout with Mike Wolfson, for real this time
description:
For our Feb 2019 meeting, we will be really covering Motion Layout with Mike Wolfson (https://twitter.com/mikewolfson). Last month, Kotlin took up most of the discussion. So this month we'll cover the complete and updated Motion Layout content from Mike.

Mike is a Product Focused Developer & #Android https://twitter.com/GoogleDevExpert. Works remote for https://twitter.com/Nerdery, speaks at conferences, collects PEZ, and wrote a book for https://twitter.com/OReillyMedia.

name: Cloud Study Jam + IoT
description:
Hello! Today . . . yes TODAY, we are working on GCP codelabs at Heatsync. We are focusing on IoT today but you are free to do whatever you want and we'll help as best we can. Below is the standard marketing pitch. We are teaming up with GDG Cloud Phoeinix who posted the event here:
https://www.meetup.com/GDG-cloud-PHX/events/258810178/

Sheldon

========

Want to get started on the Google Cloud, but don't know where to begin? Join us for our Cloud Study Jam!

Get official Google training, a $55+ value, free of charge. Together we'll work through several Google Cloud labs. You will get hands-on experience with Google Cloud’s IoT Core service and its integration with other services like GCS, Dataprep, Stackdriver and Firestore. The labs in this quest use simulator code to mimic IOT devices and the learning here should empower you to implement the same streaming pipeline with real world IoT devices.

Then after our live session, you will have free access to more labs you can finish at home. Complete all labs in the quest and earn a Google-hosted badge for your online profile, and additional 30 days access to the training platform to complete any labs you want

Bring a laptop and charger (PC, Mac or Chromebook)! The labs will run on all of the latest versions of the popular browsers. For the best experience, make sure your laptop has Firefox or Chrome installed. Don’t forget your charger.

name: Phx Android - More Cowbell ...er, Kotlin
description:
We will be continuing to study Kotlin. Josh will be presenting, which means a discussion style meetup. Target audience: all experience levels.

Some material may come from JetBrain's Kotlin Workshop. However, a good part will come from discussion covering a few specifics. Specifically, iteration in Kotlin. If that doesn't fill up the whole time, we'll try to cover some common collection functions as well.

Co-routines has also been common request, but that basically requires it's own meetup block to cover. So that won't be part of this month's discussion.

Kotlin Workshop is available content:
https://github.com/JetBrains/kotlin-workshop
